discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
As MDM Automatic Enrollment is already configured the Provisioning Package can be used to configure the Wi-Fi connection on workgroup devices before the enrollment.

Selected Answer: A
Provisioning Package fulfils both requirements. You can automatically connect devices to corp WIFI and join to Entra which will enroll devices into Intune.

A. a provisioning package.

Provisioning packages allow you to apply settings and configurations to Windows devices, including connecting to wireless networks and enrolling in Intune, without the need for Active Directory or Azure AD. This is particularly useful for devices in a workgroup environment.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/enrollment/windows-bulk-enroll
"" Join new Windows devices to Microsoft Entra ID and Intune. To bulk enroll devices for your Microsoft Entra tenant, you create a provisioning package with the Windows Configuration Designer (WCD) app. Applying the provisioning package to corporate-owned devices joins the devices to your Microsoft Entra tenant and enrolls them for Intune management. Once the package is applied, it's ready for your Microsoft Entra users to sign in. ""

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune Suite.

You use Microsoft Intune to manage devices.

Auto-enrollment in Intune is configured.

You have 100 Windows 11 devices in a workgroup.

You need to connect the devices to the corporate wireless network and enroll 100 new Windows 11 devices in Intune.

What should you use?

discussion.content: In general --> Joined: Corporate, Registered: Private
IF a device is not Entra Joined or uploaded its hash to Autopilot, the ownership always stays Personal. Registered devices are considered as Personal ownership.
Dispositivo de uso pessoal => Registered (privado) e Dispositivo de uso corporativo => Joined (empresa)

Answer is correct
See comment of BJS78
Seems correct

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 tenant that uses Microsoft Intune to manage personal and corporate devices. The tenant contains Windows 10 devices as shown in the following exhibit.

//IMG//


How will Intune classify each device after the devices are enrolled in Intune automatically? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Pause
Select Pause to prevent assigned devices from receiving feature or quality updates for up to 35 days from the time you pause the ring. After the maximum days have passed, pause functionality automatically expires and the device scans Windows Updates for applicable updates. Following this scan, you can pause the updates again. If you resume a paused update ring, and then pause that ring again, the pause period resets to 35 days.

Selected Answer: B
Correct. 
Pause feature pauses the updates for 35 days. The question itself seems ridiculous. Why would an admin need to remember exactly how many days it applies to? Thank God for MS learn during exams.

comments.content: Certification exams seem to be about memorizing content and questions versus the material itself. Need to work in the field and gain experience...that is where the skill comes from in my opinion.

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/windows-10-update-rings#pause
B is correct
What a crazy world we'd live in if Microsoft just standardised things!! Why is this 35 days yet another policy will have a default of 30. There's no need!!!!

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B
November 1st + 35 days = December 6.

Select Pause to prevent assigned devices from receiving feature or quality updates for up to 35 days from the time you pause the ring. After the maximum days have passed, pause functionality automatically expires and the device scans Windows Updates for applicable updates. Following this scan, you can pause the updates again. If you resume a paused update ring, and then pause that ring again, the pause period resets to 35 days.

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/windows-10-update-rings#pause

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune Suite.

You use Microsoft Intune to manage devices. All devices are in the same time zone.

You create an update rings policy and assign the policy to all Windows devices.

On the November 1, you pause the update rings policy.

All devices remain online.

Without further modification to the policy, on which date will the devices next attempt to update?

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that contains the devices shown in the following table.

//IMG//


All devices have Microsoft Edge installed.

From the Microsoft Intune admin center, you create a Microsoft Edge Baseline profile named Edge1.

You need to apply Edge1 to all the supported devices.

To which devices should you apply Edge1?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Security Baselines:
Edge = Windows Only
Endpoint Security = Windows Only
M365 Apps For Enterprise = Windows Only

Selected Answer: E
As of May 2023 you can configure the Edge baseline for iOS and Android, so unless the test was not updated, the answer is now E

B. Device1 and Device2 only

Microsoft Edge Baseline profiles are typically designed to enforce security and compliance settings for Microsoft Edge on Windows devices. Since Device3 is an Android device and Device4 is an iOS device, they wouldn't typically be managed using Microsoft Edge Baseline profiles from the Microsoft Intune admin center.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/security-baselines-configure

Selected Answer: B
Correct. Baseline policies are for Windows devices.
Correct

Selected Answer: B
CORRECT

Selected Answer: B
This feature applies to:
* Windows 10 version 1809 and later
* Windows 11

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/security-baselines-configure

Windows 10 and later.

Answer is correct
Edge baseline is for W10+ only

Automatic restarts are blocked between 8 AM - 5 PM.
A restart will be forced on a device 1 day after the deadline.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/windows-update-settings

comments.content: So a restart will be forced on, when? None of the available answers seem right by that

discussion.content:
Answers are correct

"Setting this value to No forces the system to wait until the deadline and grace period are expired and then restarts the device and this could occur during active hours." 

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/windows-update-settings#user-experience-settings
Grace period should be 1 day

Automatic restarts are blocked between 8 AM - 5 PM.
A restart will be forced on a device 1 day after the deadline.
Correct

- between 8 AM - 5 PM.
-1 day after the deadline.

Box1: Between 8AM and 5PM
Box2: 1 Day

Deadline - Is how long patch will stay available in Windows Update section until force installed
Grace period - Is how long until a reboot is forced.
So the correct response is 1 day until will force a reboot

The answer is wrong for no.2 - It needs to be 1 day. 
The deadline is 5 days HOWEVER, there is a grace period of 1 day so 1 day is the right answer. The grace period only takes place after the deadline has ended, and as there's a grace period of 1 day, it allows for 1 day before a device is forced into shutdown.
